content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. The Maclaurin series for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="g of x equals, the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, times x to the n power, and denominator 2 times e to the n power, plus 3, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> on its interval of convergence.(a) State the conditions necessary to use the integral test to determine convergence of the series <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator e to the n power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the integral test to show that <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator e to the n power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> converges.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. The Maclaurin series for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="g of x equals, the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, times x to the n power, and denominator 2 times e to the n power, plus 3, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> on its interval of convergence.(a) State the conditions necessary to use the integral test to determine convergence of the series <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator e to the n power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the integral test to show that <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator e to the n power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> converges.

(b) Use the limit comparison test with the series <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator e to the n power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to show that the series <math alttext="g of 1 equals, the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, and denominator 2 times e to the n power, plus 3, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> converges absolutely.
(c) Determine the radius of convergence of the Maclaurin series for <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The first two terms of the series <math alttext="g of 1 equals, the sum, from n equals 0, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, negative 1, close parenthesis, to the n power, and denominator 2 times e to the n power, plus 3, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are used to approximate <math alttext="g of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the alternating series error bound to determine an upper bound on the error of the approximation.

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
